title: Will my ESA and PIP benefits stop if I start taking my pension?
text:
Can you advise me about my superannuation pension. I have approximately £18,000 in my pension.

I took early retirement due to illness but I have been advised if I take my pension now my benefits will stop. We get ESA and I get PIP due to my condition. It's an NHS pension.

SCROLL DOWN TO FIND OUT HOW TO ASK YOUR PENSION QUESTION

Retirement dilemma: Will my disability and sickness benefits stop if I start taking my pension? (Stock image)

Steve Webb replies: Whether or not drawing an occupational pension affects your benefits depends on what sort of benefit you are getting.

There are three main categories of social security benefit.

The first type is a benefit like Personal Independence Payment (PIP) which helps you with the extra costs of being disabled.

This benefit is not means-tested (it doesn’t depend on your income) and not contributory (it is not dependent on your record of National Insurance Contributions).

Getting an occupational pension has no impact on your entitlement to this sort of benefit. This means that your PIP would continue, unaffected, if you started to draw your NHS pension.

The second type of benefit is a contributory benefit which you get based on your record of NI contributions.

Employment Support Allowance (ESA) can be paid on a contributory basis if you satisfy the contribution rules and are unable to work due to sickness.

Steve Webb: Find out how to ask the former Pensions Minister a question about your retirement savings in the box below

Contributory ESA is affected by receipt of an occupational pension but only if your weekly occupational pension is above a minimum level, currently £85 per week.

For every pound of occupational pension you have above £85 per week, your Contributory ESA is reduced by fifty pence.

The third type of benefit is a means-tested benefit which you receive because you (and your household) are on a low income and you satisfy the rules around being unable to work.

Because you say ‘we get ESA’ in your question, I’m assuming this is paid to your whole household and therefore this is likely to be means-tested ESA.

If the ESA you are receiving is indeed on a means-tested basis then your occupational pension is deducted on a pound-for-pound basis from your ESA from the very first pound of pension you receive.

If you are entitled to a large occupational pension this could completely wipe out your entitlement to ESA. (I am assuming from your question that you are due to get £18,000 a year from your NHS pension, rather than that you have a pension pot of £18,000 in total.)

You only mention ESA and PIP in your question but it is worth saying that receiving an occupational pension could also affect other means-tested benefits you may receive.

In particular, if you get help with your rent or council tax from the local authority then this could also be reduced if you start to draw an occupational pension.

Details of the DWP's benefit helplines are here. But you might prefer to contact Citizens Advice to discuss your overall financial situation.
